refined_goal:
Build a Perception-to-Production pipeline that turns a screenshot of any business UI into a running, security-audited, multi-client application stackâ€”packaged in containers, orchestrated through Model Context Protocol (MCP), and documented with auto-generated Manim animations. Concretely: use abi/screenshot-to-code to infer UI and produce Vue and iOS front-ends; synthesize a JeecgBoot backend schema and APIs from the inferred form semantics; select Go microservices from avelino/awesome-go to fill backend gaps; containerize everything with Moby; run pentest regressions from PayloadsAllTheThings against the new stack; coordinate via MCP servers; surface a cinematic SOC/dev session in Windows Terminal; and generate animated architecture explainers with Manim.
Success criteria:
- TTFP (time-to-first-productive stack): <15 minutes from screenshot to running app with two clients (web+ios) and a data-backed API.
- Security baseline: auto-run 500+ payload families with 0 criticals unhandled by default policies.
- Traceable spec: a Manim video and a machine-readable MCP transcript that fully explains what was built and why.
Why this matters: it collapses requirements discovery, prototyping, packaging, security, and documentation into a single reproducible loopâ€”turning visual intent into audited, deployable software without fragile handoffs.
repository_synergy:
THE INSIGHT
The non-obvious bridge is to treat a screenshot not only as front-end instruction but as a universal specification kernel: a source capable of seeding UI, backend schema, security assumptions, and documentation. When orchestrated via MCP, each repository becomes a controllable organ in a meta-factory: perception (screenshot-to-code), substrate (Moby), knowledge (awesome-go, awesome-vue, awesome-ios), governance (PayloadsAllTheThings), narration (Manim), enterprise scaffolding (JeecgBoot), and an operational stage (Windows Terminal). The aha moment is realizing MCP transforms these repos from static tools into addressable verbs in a single reasoning loop.

THE STORY: Why these repos
- modelcontextprotocol/servers: MCP is the missing OS for toolsâ€”simple JSON-RPC semantics enabling an AI or script to call tools predictably. It unifies the orchestra.
- moby/moby: Dockerâ€™s engine becomes the cold, deterministic substrate: immutable, isolated environments to run generators, payloads, and apps.
- abi/screenshot-to-code: Usually used for UI mockups; here, itâ€™s a schema extractor. It tells us: fields, layout, labelsâ€”signals we invert to generate databases, validators, and flows.
- avelino/awesome-go: Not a lib itself, but a curated topology of ready-made Go parts. We mine it to fill function gaps (e.g., JWT, message bus, PDF gen) in the emergent backend.
- microsoft/terminal: Ordinarily a shell. We repurpose it as a multi-pane, clickable, real-time stage manager. Dev/Sec/Docs appear as panes; OSC control and actions stitch it together.
- 3b1b/manim: Not dev tooling per se. We bend it into a spec rendererâ€”turning audit logs and data flows into pedagogical animations that double as living documentation.
- jeecgboot/JeecgBoot: A low-code enterprise base with data tables, RBAC, code gen. It accelerates the boring parts when the screenshot implies CRUD-heavy business flows.
- swisskyrepo/PayloadsAllTheThings: A living corpus of attack semantics we adapt into unit-like security regressions. Every generated endpoint gets adversarial coverage immediately.
- vuejs/awesome-vue and vsouza/awesome-ios: Librarian lists that give us the best-in-class scaffolds and plugins the moment the inferred UI needs state, charts, auth, or native bridges.

THE SYNERGY
- Visual to Schema: screenshot-to-code infers field names/types; we convert those into JeecgBoot entity definitions and Go DTOs. This closes the loop from pixels to DB.
- Knowledge Injection: A curated map from UI patterns to library choices (from awesome-* lists) yields opinionated defaults without hardcoding. For example, detect a table with filters; choose a Vue data-grid lib and a Go query builder automatically.
- Security First: Every generated route is attacked in containers via PayloadsAllTheThings. Findings feed back into code gen: validators, headers, content sniffers, rate-limiters.
- Observable by Design: We log MCP tool calls and Docker events, then render flows with Manimâ€”users can see data paths, security checkpoints, and trust boundaries animated.
- Operational Theater: Windows Terminal orchestrates panes for build, test, logs, and animation previews. It becomes a studio for interactive, reproducible development ceremonies.

THE INNOVATION
When these pieces combine, software creation is no longer linear. Itâ€™s a loop: observe (screenshot), hypothesize (UI+schema), materialize (code+containers), attack (payloads), reflect (animations/docs), and refine (MCP plan updates). This transposes prototyping into an auditable scientific method.

THE BRIDGE (Illicit Connection)
- We repurpose screenshot-to-code not only to emit HTML/CSS but to output a UI DSL that seeds JeecgBoot entities and Go types.
- We use awesome-* lists as a dynamic policy engineâ€”MCP queries them to recommend the minimal dependency set.
- We treat Windows Terminal as a programmable director using OSC sequences and JSON settings, making the terminal a composable UX surface for non-terminal artifacts (videos, dashboards).
technical_architecture:
Core topology
- Orchestrator: An MCP client/agent that plans and calls tools. It hosts prompt-programs but can be rule-based initially.
- MCP Servers:
  - mcp-docker: Wraps Docker Engine API (from Moby) for image build, run, logs, networks. Exposes: build(imageSpec), run(containerSpec), exec(id, cmd), copy(id, path), logs(id, follow).
  - mcp-s2c: Wraps abi/screenshot-to-code as a service (Python). Exposes: infer_ui(image, targets=[vue,ios,jsonSchema]), infer_schema(image) -> UI DSL.
  - mcp-jeecg: Talks to JeecgBoot codegen APIs/CLI to generate entities, controllers, and RBAC from the UI DSL. Exposes: gen_backend(schema), run_dev().
  - mcp-go-librarian: Embedding-based matcher over avelino/awesome-go index. Exposes: recommend(category, constraints), scaffold(moduleName, libs...).
  - mcp-vue-librarian / mcp-ios-librarian: Similar matchers for awesome-vue and awesome-ios.
  - mcp-payloads: Curated runners that pull PayloadsAllTheThings payload sets and execute via HTTP/WebSocket/GraphQL against live containers. Exposes: attack(surface, profile), report().
  - mcp-manim: Python service that converts an event graph (tool calls, routes, data stores, trust boundaries) into a Manim scene and renders mp4/gif. Exposes: render(diagramSpec).
  - mcp-terminal: Thin adapter to Windows Terminal via wt.exe and settings.json templates; also emits OSC sequences to label panes and hyperlinks. Exposes: layout(panes), runInPane(cmds...).

Data flow (happy path)
1) Perception: Orchestrator calls mcp-s2c.infer_ui(image, [vue,ios,jsonSchema]). Output: Vue components scaffold, SwiftUI scaffold, and UI DSL (fields, actions, navigation).
2) Schema synthesis: Orchestrator transforms UI DSL into a domain model: entities, relationships, validations. Calls mcp-jeecg.gen_backend(model). Output: Java Spring Boot services, DB migrations, auth scaffold.
3) Capability fill: For non-CRUD operations inferred (charts, export, notifications), orchestrator queries mcp-go-librarian and mcp-vue-librarian to select libs (e.g., go-chi for routing, sqlx for DB, vueuse for composables). If a Go microservice is better suited (e.g., streaming), mcp-docker scaffolds a Go service alongside JeecgBoot and wires via Docker compose networks.
4) Packaging: mcp-docker builds images for frontends (vite/webpack), backend (JeecgBoot), and optional Go services, composes them, and launches a network.
5) Security regression: mcp-payloads.attack(surface=auto-discovered routes, profile=web_api_default). Generates a findings graph; orchestrator patches codegen parameters (e.g., CSP headers, size limits, encoding) and re-runs.
6) Narration: Collect MCP call logs + Docker events into an event graph, feed to mcp-manim.render(diagramSpec). Output: a narrated animation of the architecture, request flows, and security hardening steps.
7) Operational stage: mcp-terminal.layout defines panes: Build, Backend Logs, Frontend Logs, Security Run, Manim Preview. Orchestrator keeps links clickable via OSC 8 (hyperlinks) and labels via OSC 0/133.

APIs and interfaces
- MCP JSON-RPC over stdio or WebSocket. Tool schemas versioned by JSON Schema; strong typing ensures portability.
- Docker: REST API on /var/run/docker.sock or TCP. BuildKit enabled for speed and layer caching.
- Payload runners use Python requests/locust for HTTP, websockets for WS, and graphql-python for GraphQL. Profiles reference PayloadsAllTheThings directories.
- mcp-go-librarian uses a local embedding index (MiniLM or fastText) over the awesome-go repo metadata; cosine similarity plus rule filters (MIT/Apache only, recent commits) yields recommendations.

Key challenges and solutions
- UI DSL fidelity: Screenshots are noisy. We add a two-pass inference: (a) screenshot-to-code; (b) heuristic semantic parse (e.g., label-input adjacency, button verbs to CRUD mapping). Human-in-the-loop diffs via MCP provide corrections quickly.
- Backend mismatch (Java vs Go): We treat JeecgBoot as the authoritative CRUD engine and deploy Go for stateless edge functions (streaming, image processing). Use Docker networks and an API gateway (e.g., Traefik) to unify.
- Security test breadth vs safety: Run payloads in a sand-boxed network; rate-limit and tag destructive payloads. Automatically snapshot DB volumes pre-test and restore post-test.
- Performance: BuildKit cache mounts, parallel Docker builds, and model caching for s2c. For repeated iterations, keep long-lived containers warm.
- Windows Terminal portability: On non-Windows, provide a tmux-compatible mcp-terminal variant with similar pane orchestration.

Non-obvious optimizations
- Differential re-generation: Cache the UI DSL. On changes, regenerate only affected components and DB migrations.
- Static affordance hints: Infer accessibility labels and testids during generation to improve e2e testability and later screenshot diffs.
- Payload prioritization: Use route entropy (number of parameters, body complexity) to prioritize payload sets, reducing time-to-signal.
- Manim template library: Pre-baked scenes for CRUD vs event-driven patterns accelerate rendering and make animations coherent.

Integration patterns
- Everything is a containerized tool behind an MCP server. That keeps hermeticity and makes cloud/offline parity easy.
- The orchestration transcript is a first-class artifact. A build is reproducible from the transcript alone.
- Librarian servers are pure data + ranking; swapping curated lists or policies requires no code changes in the generators.
expected_impact:
Use cases
1) Legacy Form Resurrection: A hospital has a screenshot of a 2012-era patient intake form. In 15 minutes, the system produces a Vue web app and an iOS intake app backed by JeecgBoot, with Go microservices for PDF export and HL7 parsing. Payload runs confirm inputs are sanitized against common injection vectors; Manim outputs an animation for the compliance board.
2) Red-Team Ready Prototypes: A fintech team sketches a money transfer flow on a whiteboard, grabs a photo, and gets a runnable stack. Before any user sees it, PayloadsAllTheThings executes SSRF/XXE/IDOR checks against the services, and the orchestrator teaches the codegen to enforce object-level permissions and rate limits.
3) Data Room-in-a-Box: A merger due diligence requires a sanitized data portal. Using screenshots of desired pages, the system builds a disposable, containerized portal with one-click teardown. An animated architecture brief narrates data flow and access controls for legal sign-off.
4) CLI-to-Web Bridge: A legacy CLI tool is screenshotted with its options. The system infers form controls, generates a Vue front-end and a Go wrapper service that shells the CLI in a container. Security tests apply payloads to the wrapper endpoints.
5) Mobile Parity Sprint: Product wants iOS parity for a subset of screens. Feed screenshots; get SwiftUI scaffolds wired to the same backend and auth flows. A curated awesome-ios pass picks a charts lib and offline storage lib based on inferred requirements.
6) Teaching Secure Architecture: In a bootcamp, instructors demonstrate how payloads map to code changes. Students watch Manim animations that show where inputs enter, how theyâ€™re validated, and how headers/CSP mitigate attacks.
7) Regulated Environments: Air-gapped orgs run the entire stack on a bastion using Docker offline caches. Librarians point to vetted, whitelisted libs only.

Scalability and extensibility
- New front-end targets (e.g., Flutter) are just new mcp-* servers and DSL mappers.
- Security profiles can grow per domain (e.g., healthcare HIPAA payload profiles).
- The librarian indexes refresh asynchronously; recommendations improve without rebuilding the pipeline.

Limitations and mitigations
- Inference errors: Visual ambiguities lead to wrong field types. Mitigate with a quick human-in-the-loop correction UI and tests seeded from real sample data.
- Domain logic gap: Nontrivial workflows are hard to infer from a screenshot. Encourage adding a second artifact (a short natural language spec) that MCP treats as authoritative overrides.
- Payload safety: Some payloads may be destructive. Run on temp databases with snapshots and strict network egress rules.
- Vendor lock-in perception: Mixing Java and Go may raise ops complexity. Provide a Docker Compose and Helm chart that standardize deployment and health checks.
- Performance of Manim: Rendering can be slow. Provide low-res previews and render final cuts in a GPU-accelerated container after hours.
innovation_analysis:
Innovation score: 9/10. The illicit bridgesâ€”treating screenshot-to-code as schema discoverer, using awesome-* repos as a dynamic policy engine, and turning Windows Terminal into an orchestrated studioâ€”are genuinely non-obvious and synergistic. Security regression as a first-class generative step plus auto-animated documentation closes a loop few systems consider.
Immediate next steps:
- Build mcp-s2c and mcp-docker minimal servers; wire a PoC flow from screenshot to Vue scaffold to Dockerized run.
- Implement the UI DSL and a minimal mapper to JeecgBoot entities; stand up mcp-jeecg codegen.
- Integrate a small payload profile (input validation) and the Manim event-graph renderer.
Key metrics:
- TTFP from screenshot to running app, number of developer interventions needed, criticals found by payloads pre- vs post-hardening, rebuild time after incremental changes, doc generation latency.
Essential tools/frameworks:
- MCP SDK (TypeScript/Python), Docker Engine/BuildKit, abi/screenshot-to-code models, JeecgBoot CLI/APIs, Python Manim, embedding model for librarian servers, Windows Terminal wt.exe/OSC integration, Traefik or Nginx for routing.

sources.name: modelcontextprotocol/servers
sources.readme_snippet:
# Model Context Protocol servers

This repository is a collection of *reference implementations* for the [Model Context Protocol](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/) (MCP), as well as references to community-built servers and additional resources.

The servers in this repository showcase the versatility and extensibility of MCP, demonstrating how it can be used to give Large Language Models (LLMs) secure, controlled access to tools and data sources.
Typically, each MCP server is implemented with an MCP SDK:

- [C# MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/csharp-sdk)
- [Go MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/go-sdk)
- [Java MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/java-sdk)
- [Kotlin MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/kotlin-sdk)
- [PHP MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/php-sdk)
- [Python MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/python-sdk)
- [Ruby MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/ruby-sdk)
- [Rust MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/rust-sdk)
- [Swift MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/swift-sdk)
- [TypeScript MCP SDK](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/typescript-sdk)

> [!NOTE]
> Lists in this README are maintained in alphabetical order to minimize merge conflicts when adding new items.

## ğŸŒŸ Reference Servers

These servers aim to demonstrate MCP features and the official SDKs.

- **[Everything](src/everything)** - Reference / test server with prompts, resources, and tools.
- **[Fetch](src/fetch)** - Web content fetching and conversion for efficient LLM usage.
- **[Filesystem](src/filesystem)** - Secure file operations with configurable access controls.
- **[Git](src/git)** - Tools to read, search, and manipulate Git repositories.
- **[Memory](src/memory)** - Knowledge graph-based persistent memory system.
- **[Sequential Thinking](src/sequentialthinking)** - Dynamic and reflective problem-solving through thought sequences.
- **[Time](src/time)** - Time

sources.name: moby/moby
sources.readme_snippet:
The Moby Project
================

[![PkgGoDev](https://pkg.go.dev/badge/github.com/moby/moby/v2)](https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/moby/moby/v2)
![GitHub License](https://img.shields.io/github/license/moby/moby)
[![Go Report Card](https://goreportcard.com/badge/github.com/moby/moby/v2)](https://goreportcard.com/report/github.com/moby/moby/v2)
[![OpenSSF Scorecard](https://api.scorecard.dev/projects/github.com/moby/moby/badge)](https://scorecard.dev/viewer/?uri=github.com/moby/moby)
[![OpenSSF Best Practices](https://www.bestpractices.dev/projects/10989/badge)](https://www.bestpractices.dev/projects/10989)


![Moby Project logo](docs/static_files/moby-project-logo.png "The Moby Project")

Moby is an open-source project created by Docker to enable and accelerate software containerization.

It provides a "Lego set" of toolkit components, the framework for assembling them into custom container-based systems, and a place for all container enthusiasts and professionals to experiment and exchange ideas.
Components include container build tools, a container registry, orchestration tools, a runtime and more, and these can be used as building blocks in conjunction with other tools and projects.

## Principles

Moby is an open project guided by strong principles, aiming to be modular, flexible and without too strong an opinion on user experience.
It is open to the community to help set its direction.

- Modular: the project includes lots of components that have well-defined functions and APIs that work together.
- Batteries included but swappable: Moby includes enough components to build fully featured container systems, but its modular architecture ensures that most of the components can be swapped by different implementations.
- Usable security: Moby provides secure defaults without compromising usability.
- Developer focused: The APIs are intended to be functional and useful to build powerful tools.
They are not necessarily intended as end user tools but as components aimed a

sources.name: abi/screenshot-to-code
sources.readme_snippet:
# screenshot-to-code

A simple tool to convert screenshots, mockups and Figma designs into clean, functional code using AI. Now supporting Claude Sonnet 3.7!

https://github.com/abi/screenshot-to-code/assets/23818/6cebadae-2fe3-4986-ac6a-8fb9db030045

Supported stacks:

- HTML + Tailwind
- HTML + CSS
- React + Tailwind
- Vue + Tailwind
- Bootstrap
- Ionic + Tailwind
- SVG

Supported AI models:

- Claude Sonnet 3.7 - Best model!
- GPT-4o - also recommended!
- DALL-E 3 or Flux Schnell (using Replicate) for image generation

See the [Examples](#-examples) section below for more demos.

We also just added experimental support for taking a video/screen recording of a website in action and turning that into a functional prototype.

![google in app quick 3](https://github.com/abi/screenshot-to-code/assets/23818/8758ffa4-9483-4b9b-bb66-abd6d1594c33)

[Learn more about video here](https://github.com/abi/screenshot-to-code/wiki/Screen-Recording-to-Code).

[Follow me on Twitter for updates](https://twitter.com/_abi_).

## ğŸŒ Hosted Version

[Try it live on the hosted version (paid)](https://screenshottocode.com).

## ğŸ›  Getting Started

The app has a React/Vite frontend and a FastAPI backend.

Keys needed:

- [OpenAI API key with access to GPT-4](https://github.com/abi/screenshot-to-code/blob/main/Troubleshooting.md) or Anthropic key (optional)
- Both are recommended so you can compare results from both Claude and GPT4o

If you'd like to run the app with Ollama open source models (not recommended due to poor quality results), [follow this comment](https://github.com/abi/screenshot-to-code/issues/354#issuecomment-2435479853).

Run the backend (I use Poetry for package management - `pip install --upgrade poetry` if you don't have it):

```bash
cd backend
echo "OPENAI_API_KEY=sk-your-key" > .env
echo "ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=your-key" > .env
poetry install
poetry shell
poetry run uvicorn main:app --reload --port 7001
```

You can also set up the keys using the settings dialog on the fron

sources.name: 3b1b/manim
sources.readme_snippet: [![pypi version](https://img.shields.io/pypi/v/manimgl?logo=pypi)](https://pypi.org/project/manimgl/) [![MIT License](https://img.shields.io/badge/license-MIT-blue.svg?style=flat)](http://choosealicense.com/licenses/mit/) [![Manim Subreddit](https://img.shields.io/reddit/subreddit-subscribers/manim.svg?color=ff4301&label=reddit&logo=reddit)](https://www.reddit.com/r/manim/) [![Manim Discord](https://img.shields.io/discord/581738731934056449.svg?label=discord&logo=discord)](https://discord.com/invite/bYCyhM9Kz2) [![docs](https://github.com/3b1b/manim/workflows/docs/badge.svg)](https://3b1b.github.io/manim/) Manim is an engine for precise programmatic animations, designed for creating explanatory math videos. Note, there are two versions of manim. This repository began as a personal project by the author of [3Blue1Brown](https://www.3blue1brown.com/) for the purpose of animating those videos, with video-specific code available [here](https://github.com/3b1b/videos). In 2020 a group of developers forked it into what is now the [community edition](https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim/), with a goal of being more stable, better tested, quicker to respond to community contributions, and all around friendlier to get started with. See [this page](https://docs.manim.community/en/stable/faq/installation.html#different-versions) for more details. ## Installation > [!Warning] > **WARNING:** These instructions are for ManimGL _only_. Trying to use these instructions to install [Manim Community/manim](https://github.com/ManimCommunity/manim) or instructions there to install this version will cause problems. You should first decide which version you wish to install, then only follow the instructions for your desired version. > [!Note] > **Note**: To install manim directly through pip, please pay attention t

sources.name: swisskyrepo/PayloadsAllTheThings
sources.readme_snippet:
# Payloads All The Things A list of useful payloads and bypasses for Web Application Security. Feel free to improve with your payloads and techniques! You can also contribute with a :beers: IRL, or using the sponsor button. [![Sponsor](https://img.shields.io/static/v1?label=Sponsor&message=%E2%9D%A4&logo=GitHub&link=https://github.com/sponsors/swisskyrepo)](https://github.com/sponsors/swisskyrepo) [![Tweet](https://img.shields.io/twitter/url/http/shields.io.svg?style=social)](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=Payloads%20All%20The%20Things,%20a%20list%20of%20useful%20payloads%20and%20bypasses%20for%20Web%20Application%20Security%20-%20by%20@pentest_swissky&url=https://github.com/swisskyrepo/PayloadsAllTheThings/) An alternative display version is available at [PayloadsAllTheThingsWeb](https://swisskyrepo.github.io/PayloadsAllTheThings/).

## :book: Documentation Every section contains the following files, you can use the `_template_vuln` folder to create a new chapter: - README.md - vulnerability description and how to exploit it, including several payloads - Intruder - a set of files to give to Burp Intruder - Images - pictures for the README.md - Files - some files referenced in the README.md You might also like the other projects from the AllTheThings family : - [InternalAllTheThings](https://swisskyrepo.github.io/InternalAllTheThings/) - Active Directory and Internal Pentest Cheatsheets - [HardwareAllTheThings](https://swisskyrepo.github.io/HardwareAllTheThings/) - Hardware/IOT Pentesting Wiki You want more? Check the [Books](https://github.com/swisskyrepo/PayloadsAllTheThings/blob/master/_LEARNING_AND_SOCIALS/BOOKS.md) and [YouTube channel](https://github.com/swisskyrepo/PayloadsAllTheThings/blob/master/_LEARNING_AND_SOCIALS/YOUTUBE.md) selections. ## :technologist: Contributions Be sure to read [CONTRIBU

sources.name: vuejs/awesome-vue
sources.readme_snippet: ## Awesome Vue.js [![Awesome](https://cdn.rawgit.com/sindresorhus/awesome/d7305f38d29fed78fa85652e3a63e154dd8e8829/media/badge.svg)](https://github.com/sindresorhus/awesome) [![Track Awesome List](https://www.trackawesomelist.com/badge.svg)](https://www.trackawesomelist.com/vuejs/awesome-vue) > A curated list of awesome things related to Vue.js - [Awesome Vue.js ](#awesome-vuejs--) - [Resources](#resources) - [Official Resources](#official-resources) - [External Resources](#external-resources) - [Job Portal](#job-portal) - [Community](#community) - [Conferences](#conferences) - [Podcasts](#podcasts) - [Official Examples](#official-examples) - [Tutorials](#tutorials) - [Examples](#examples) - [Books](#books) - [Blog Posts](#blog-posts) - [Courses](#courses) - [Documentaries](#documentaries) - [Companies Using Vue.js](#companies-using-vuejs) - [Projects Using Vue.js](#projects-using-vuejs) - [Open Source](#open-source) - [Commercial Products](#commercial-products) - [Apps/Websites](#appswebsites) - [Interactive Experiences](#interactive-experiences) - [Enterprise Usage](#enterprise-usage) - [A11y](#a11y) - [Components \& Libraries](#components--libraries) - [Frameworks](#frameworks) - [Responsive](#responsive) - [Mobile](#mobile) - [Component Collections](#component-collections) - [Admin Template](#admin-template) - [Server-side rendering](#server-side-rendering) - [Static website generator](#static-website-generator) - [Other](#other) - [UI Layout](#ui-layout) - [UI Components](#ui-components) - [Table](#table) - [Notification](#notification) - [Loader](#loader) - [Progress Bar](#progress-bar) - [Tooltip](#tooltip) - [Overlay](#overlay) - [Icons](#icons) - [Marquee](#marquee) - [Menu](#menu) - [Carousel](#carousel) - [Chart

sources.name: vsouza/awesome-ios
sources.readme_snippet:
This project is supported by:

## Contributing and Collaborating Please see [CONTRIBUTING](https://github.com/vsouza/awesome-ios/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md) and [CODE-OF-CONDUCT](https://github.com/vsouza/awesome-ios/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md) for details. ## Contents - [Analytics](#analytics) - [App Routing](#app-routing) - [Apple TV](#apple-tv) - [App Store](#app-store) - [Architecture Patterns](#architecture-patterns) - [ARKit](#arkit) - [Authentication](#authentication) - [Blockchain](#blockchain) - [Books](#books) - [Cache](#cache) - [Charts](#charts) - [Code Injection](#code-injection) - [Code Quality](#code-quality) - [Linter](#linter) - [Color](#color) - [Command Line](#command-line) - [Concurrency](#concurrency) - [Core Data](#core-data) - [Courses](#courses) - [Getting Started](#getting-started) - [Database](#database) - [Data Structures / Algorithms](#data-structures--algorithms) - [Date & Time](#date--time) - [Debugging](#debugging) - [Dependency Injection](#dependency-injection) - [Dependency / Package Manager](#dependency--package-manager) - [Deployment / Distribution](#deployment--distribution) - [EventBus](#eventbus) - [Files](#files) - [Functional Programming](#functional-programming) - [Games](#games) - [GCD](#gcd) - [Gesture](#gesture) - [Graphics](#graphics) - [Hardware](#hardw

blueprint.title: GitRecombo â€” Outâ€‘ofâ€‘Scale Blueprint
blueprint.summary: Recombination of recent GitHub innovations with long-tail exploration, health/reputation signals, and optional semantic relevance.
blueprint.architecture_ascii:
[1] modelcontextprotocol/servers  â†’  [2] moby/moby  â†’  [3] abi/screenshot-to-code  â†’  [4] avelino/awesome-go  â†’  [5] microsoft/terminal  â†’  [6] 3b1b/manim  â†’  [7] jeecgboot/JeecgBoot  â†’  [8] swisskyrepo/PayloadsAllTheThings  â†’  [9] vuejs/awesome-vue  â†’  [10] vsouza/awesome-ios

why_it_works: Novelty + Health + Author signals + Semantic relevance elevate hidden gems.
Diversity bonus avoids conceptual duplicates when embeddings are enabled.
Permissive licensing keeps integration safe and fast.
